entry.title: Set Up My Blog
entry.content:
I previously used my secondary Facebook account as a blog, but soon I felt need for another platform. I wanted to open my posting with my editor (emacs, org-mode) and update with my VCS (git). Simple static web site looked fine for me, as Discourse or Disqus seems to provide satisfiable commenting feature. I’ve looked through some examples below.

  • org web sites
  • org blogging tools
  • cse3521-website

As a total newbie on web front-end programming, org-mode, elisp, and blogging, I

  • myself doesn’t know exactly which feature I want.
  • am hard to deal with problems when I stuck.

Therefore, large and active community was especially important factor for me.

Blogging tool

o-blog

stuck with this issue : https://github.com/renard/o-blog/issues/116#issuecomment-59183307

Octopress with org-octopress

I also noticed this post and tried it. I’m not sure of pros and cons of each, but I followed upper link because

  • It looks simpler.
  • It is in Elpa package list, while the other is not.
  • More recent, more users (concerning github stars)
  • newer post of this blog suggests to use it, while the older post of this blog suggests to use the other.

Jekyll

It seems also reasonable to use pure Jekyll, but I haven’t tried.

Deploying tool

Heroku

I followed instructions but somehow it didn’t work for me.

Github page

It works.

Had trouble with table styling, it didn’t have any border. I followed this to resolve. Anyway, this styling doesn’t work when table is placed after title. (here, “Table Styling”) I’m total noob on front-end and I was only able to check with Chrome developer tool - magnifier, that the table is “screen.css”, not “data-table.css”.

_posts directory

Added .gitignore to ignore “source/_posts” directory. I think this directory is managed in “org-octopress” only, and Html files there can be recoverd from .org files.

rake preview, rvm

I had a problem which I cannot remember well. After some troubleshooting, it turned out it was matter of gem versions. I executed “gem list” in M-x shell, M-x term, M-x eshell, original terminal, respectively and it turned out to have 2 equiv. class.

shell = term

original terminal = eshell

(login shell?) I resolved it by https://github.com/senny/rvm.el With this and some rvm works, I have same gem lists for each shell.
